Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery cup, probably a band-cup; interior glazed black; exterior: in handle zone, black-figure decoration consisting of upper part of dancing maenad (hair tied back in knot, thin faded added red necklace, red belted garment with double incised lines at neck and upper arms) looking to left but probably moving to right; right hand in faded added white held in front of body and left hand raised; to right, part of a satyr (back, ear, red hair and trace of red beard); inscription in field.
Curator's comments: The two incised lines at the top of the ‘satyr’s’ buttock suggest he may have been wearing a costume. Perhaps the figure is a padded dancer.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B601.22)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 440, no. B718)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0457) (Phase 1)
